title: When will the next Italian general election occur?
preds: I doubt anything will happen in the next week.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-politics-election/italian-senate-approves-electoral-law-likely-to-produce-hung-parliament-idUSKBN1CV1CQ "Italy’s upper house Senate approved on Thursday a new electoral system that is expected to handicap the anti-establishment 5-Star Movement at a forthcoming national election and favor mainstream political blocs.  The bill has already been approved by the lower house thanks to a battery of confidence motions that swept aside all opposition and now only needs a green light from the head of state to become law. This is expected in the coming days. The voting system, a mix of proportional representation and first-past-the-post, will benefit parties that form pre-election coalitions -- something the 5-Star has always ruled out. With opinion polls pointing to a three-way split between the centre-left, centre-right and 5-Star, analysts say the new electoral law will not produce a clear-cut winner at the next election, which is due by May 2018."
No serious talk of snap elections since June.

A strong agreement in which Italy commits to reducing its debt to GDP ratio through stronger growth.... in exchange for a return for at least five years... with deficit at 2.9 percent," he wrote, adding this would be the PD's agenda for the next general election, due by May 2018. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-renzi-idUSKBN19U0CV?il=0
Stalled agreement on early elections. But you never know.
Do the recent British elections have any forbearing???  Don't wake up the dead.....
Well, Renzi appears to have given up on early elections, until further notice. So much for this excitement. Back to baseline.

Italy's Padoan Welcomes 'Gigantic' IMF Growth Revision (ANSA)
Economy Minister Pier Carlo Padoan today welcomed the IMF's upward revision of its 2017 growth forecast for Italy. "The IMF has revised up its growth forecast for Italy by 0.5-0.6 of a percentage point, from 0.7-0.8% to 1.3%. These are gigantic figures for those who make forecasts, beyond even the most optimistic estimates of the Treasury. I'm pleased; I'm not fully satisfied, but I'm not astounded," he said. Italy is set to hold elections early next year at the latest and Padoan said that the reforms the government is pursuing must continue in the next parliamentary term. "The government is continuing to pursue the policy of reforms, and it will keep doing so, in the awareness that the next parliament will have to push ahead the country's potential

Looks like the impetus to have elections in Q3 has waned. This can happen only on the basis of the existing law, and there doesn't seem to exist much appetite for that (even though small parties may support that). 
The local election results have interesting and yet unknown implications. The financial markets seem to have taken 5SM's losses as a sign that elections will be in 2018. But this assumes that PD would be OK with taking the blame (via Gentilloni's government) for a tough 2018 budget. An alternative interpretation is that Renzi may be emboldened by 5SM's losses, while Grillo would like to salvage what he can from his party's popularity. So we may yet see elections in Q4.
I'm incredibly far behind on this question. This will ding my score.

https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-06-12/italy-s-anti-euro-five-star-movement-suffers-election-setbacks "Italy’s opposition Five Star Movement suffered heavy setbacks in local elections on Sunday, dimming the party’s prospects of leading the national government after parliamentary elections next year. Five Star, led by former comedian Beppe Grillo, failed to make it to the second round of voting in Genoa, Palermo, Parma and Verona, according to projections. Centrist-oriented parties fared better in the approximately 1,000 towns and cities that voted, with the second round scheduled for June 25. Turnout was just over 60 percent. A multi-party deal on a new electoral law unraveled last week, making it highly unlikely that a snap national vote will be held this year."

I  guess, as much as some would want the elections to happen this year, it may not.
The electoral reform group unraveled and the bill went back to committee - dead?
http://www.italy24.ilsole24ore.com/art/politics/2017-06-08/italian-electoral-law-has-lost-the-support-of-major-parties-182329.php?uuid=AE33BEbB

Adjusting, but only a little... Situation is unclear by now. That the electoral deal unraveled is not a clear signal for elections in 2018. It could easily turn out to be noise. Because: The gov is shaken. That is an argument in favor of snap elections. To my mind, the pressure to clear the situation has grown a little. We will probably soon know what happens next. But Italy is Italy is Italy!
Today's failure of the election reform legislation in the lower house, combined with Renzi resigning himself to a 2018 election definitely pushes me more to 2018.

Reaffirming forecast. Call it confirmation bias, but in my view not much has changed since yesterday as far as our question is concerned. The political will of all major parties to hold elections as soon as possible remains. Two major possibilities: (i) hold elections quickly, based on the current law (as 5SM suggests) - meaning elections in Q3, or (ii) (more likely) go back to the drawing board and reach a new agreement - the delay could push the date to Q4. It's also possible that the local elections on Sunday change the mind of some large parties (if they do poorly, they may turn against early elections), but this is covered by my 15% probability for 2018.

"Italy ruling party says deal on new electoral law 'dead', markets rally A deal struck among Italy's main political parties over a new electoral law has unraveled, a senior figure from the ruling Democratic Party (PD) said on Thursday after his group lost a parliamentary vote on a proposed amendment. "The accord on the electoral law is dead," Emanuele Fiano, who presented the law being debated in the Chamber of Deputies, told reporters. He blamed the anti-establishment 5-Star Movement, saying they had "killed off" the deal. Italian assets gained on signs the accord was failing, with government bond yields falling and stocks rising as investors bet the breakdown of the accord would reduce the risk of a snap election this year. However, some politicians predicted that the row could make a vote in 2017 more likely, saying the government might decide to circumvent a divided parliament and introduce a new electoral system by decree. Italy's main parties -- the PD, 5-Star, Silvio Berlusconi's Forza Italia and the right-wing Northern League -- agreed last week that they would all support a proportional representation system based on the German electoral model. However, as soon as voting on the bill began in the lower house this week, the agreement began to look shaky. On Wednesday some 60 parliamentarians opposed it in secret ballots, with the PD and 5-Star blaming each other for the defections.
Fiano declared the deal dead on Thursday after an amendment, opposed by the PD, regarding elections in the autonomous northern region of Trentino Alto-Adige, was passed in a secret vote. PD lawmakers said the 5-Star had backed the measure. Alessandro Di Battista, one of 5-Star's most prominent deputies, accused the PD of wanting to scupper the new electoral law and using the Trentino vote as a pretext. "For us the pact is still valid, we are in favor of this bill," he told reporters.
Voting on the bill was suspended and the PD, Forza Italia and the Northern League convened meetings of their executive bodies to decide the next step. The Northern League called for a new electoral law to be introduced by emergency decree so that a snap vote could be held, and PD spokesman Matteo Richetti also suggested it would be better to go to the polls quickly. "If parliament ... can't agree on an electoral law it's hard to argue that the legislature can carry on," he said. The legislature is due to end by May 2018." http://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-politics-idUSKBN18Z1JE?il=0 Note: Tomorrow everything can be completely different again

The three largest political parties have decided that they want elections this year - before the tough 2018 budget is passed and before the ECB stops purchasing sovereign bonds. Neither Mattarella nor Gentilloni can prevent that just because they want to. Still, what can push the elections to 2018: (i) not passing the electoral law before Q4 (unlikely now), or (ii) Alfano has said that the draft law in its current form is unconstitutional - if he goes to the Constitutional Court after passage, this can delay things. But this is not guaranteed, as the draft law can be amended or he can change his mind. Anyway, 2018 warrants now only a small probability in my view. Differentiating between Q3 and Q4 is tougher. Given the situation with the electoral law, Sep 24 seems just about the only date in Q3 that may work. But this is Renzi's preferred date, and Grillo doesn't mind it either. Still, passage of the electoral law may be delayed by a couple of weeks, or the law can be challenged in court. Until we get more clarity on these matters, I'd assign a higher probability to Q4. The EC deadline is not a problem - the EC will wait for Italy.
Based on arguments by @Rene and @ErikFritzsche below http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/516025

From what I can decipher, it looks like 24 September is a real possibilty. That would give the new government enough time to set up a 'budget law' (? - budget for 2018?), whose deadline is 15 October. Three weeks is enough? Still not certain that the new voting law will make it though. http://www.corriere.it/politica/17_giugno_07/quirinale-si-prepara-scenario-3bf65d8a-4af3-11e7-ac11-205c7f1cfc9f.shtml
See http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/515789 ... and my comment on this.

“Italy's Constitutional Affairs Committee on Monday signed off on a new electoral law after the main parties reached a deal which could pave the way to a national election in the autumn.
Deputies will begin debating the law, which is based on proportional representation, on Tuesday, and party leaders say they hope it can be approved in both houses in early July.”
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-politics-idUSKBN18W2C1
SO this is really happening. The Italians seem to have agreed on a form of voting that the three main parties are willing to support. But this agreement obviously makes the risk of early vote more likely. Of course there is still that pesky problem of EU budget deadlines…
“Italy will not only adopt the German voting system, but may even end up voting on the same day - September 24 - or possibly a week earlier, as La Republica writes this morning” 
“Frankfurter Allgemeine’s Rome correspondent sees a financial crisis coming up in the autumn because it will be impossible for the new government to agree on a 2018 budget in time. The article argues that both Renzi and Luigi Di Maio, the Five Star’s top parliamentarian, both want early elections because they do not want to be bound by the 2018 austerity budget that would otherwise be decided for them by the current administration.”
https://www.eurointelligence.com/public.html
So it appears that my initial thoughts that the budget process was a reason to pause on elections was wrong. In fact, Five Start and Renzi may both want to hold earlier elections in order to get ahead of the budget process, even if that means missing the October deadline
But…
Italian Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni said parliament should decide between a general election as early as September or wait until the end of the legislature at the beginning of next year to hold fresh elections.
http://www.politico.eu/article/italy-election-renzi-paolo-gentiloni-early-elections-should-not-disrupt-eu-commitments/
But it’s not really up to him, it’s Matarella. And most commentators believe that Matarella does not want to risk messing up the budget process, especially when there is a risk of either a M5S/LN coalition, or a PD/FI coalition, or a hung parliament. FWIW I appreciate that M5S has said they won’t engage in any alliances but if they are that close to taking power they may change their tune.
I think the framing of this question makes it a little hard. If September/October is the time frame then having the cut-off be September forces one to spread their bets across those two dates. I think that if they can’t get the voting law approved before July, however, then there is no way Matarella will dissolve parliament. 
Given the timing of the EU deadlines, I think the balance of the risk in 2017 has to fall towards the July-September bucket, but October is possible. 
Does anyone know if there are specific constitutional guidelines for the election i.e. how many days after the dissolution of parliament it would have to happen? It was 65 days after the collapse of the Monti government in 2012.  also h/t to @ricofig and @anneinak for links
Haven't touched this one in a long time. Way behind the curve.
With a new electoral law signed, we may see general elections in the fall. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-politics-idUSKBN18W2C1

http://www.politico.eu/article/italy-election-renzi-paolo-gentiloni-early-elections-should-not-disrupt-eu-commitments/ Italian Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni said parliament should decide between a general election as early as September or wait until the end of the legislature at the beginning of next year to hold fresh elections.

Bumping up the H2 probability in light of renewed talk about early elections in the Autumn, however feel it unlikely that this will happen. With tough measures from the EC coming up in the autumn, along with ECB bond purchase tapering, Italy has no need to voluntarily further worsen its cost of financing. A new (probably hung) parliament will not be any more capable in resolving Italy's structural problems. There are also clear signs of election fatigue, and Renzi need only look at the UK to see what that can do to incumbent parties' support. With Italian politics though rationality is not always the preferred option. https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-05-31/italy-doesn-t-need-early-elections

Adjusting to take account of reports over the last few days that the major Italian political parties will be able to agree on a new electoral law on the German model, allowing the President to agree to elections as early as the fall.  However, I find it hard to understand why Renzi thinks it's in his party's interest to call early elections when his PD and Grillo's 5SM are both around 30% in the polls (and especially when he called a referendum just a few months ago, only to lose it badly). Even if he thinks the PD is going to lose further popularity by next year, it would be more logical to wait and hope for a change by May 2018 rather than face likely defeat this year.

They are serious in Italy:
http://www.cnbc.com/2017/05/30/heres-why-the-chances-of-a-snap-election-in-italy-are-increasing-considerably.html  Reseting with a chimpanzee on my laps!

I am changing my mind. With both Renzi and Grillo pushing for a September election date, this outcome acquires a non-trivial probability. Apparently, the campaign will be short. And I understand that the MPs will still get pensions if the date is after Sep 15. Still, this push may not be successful, if the smaller parties manage to delay the passage of the new electoral law, or the President delays the elections one way or another (not a large probability, in my mind). But if not Q3, then Q4 - the budget will have to wait. Apparently, Renzi has decided that a tough 2018 budget - required by the EC - will be blamed on PD, and Grillo is concerned that the European tide may be turning against the populists and wants to capitalize on 5SM's still high popularity.

There is much uncertainty in this forecast... the financial market argument: did not see this coming. I balance my forecast a bit towards this year's options...
https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-05-29/italy-moves-toward-early-elections-as-voting-rules-deal-nears Thank you @Rstamme for your comment: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/511894  On the other hand: They need time to fight down 5SM... their polls are incredible. If the political establishment in Italy is not able to have a new electoral law and if the President would stop snap elections, thinks become worse, I guess. But all forecasters out there: Be warned! Italian politics is incredibly complicated.

Adjusting from 10% in Q4 and 90% thereafter to reflect current political consensus. Current discussion shows a basic agreement among the major Italian political forces on a new electoral law and timing of new elections in autumn. Dates traded are past September 10 but before approval of the 2018 budget to be submitted to the EU Commission, due at the end of October (logic: vote before you become unpopular for raising taxes). Excluding timing that leads to political and legislative stalling just when the budget needs to be approved that leaves a small corridor in the second half of September; I believe October to be too tight to have a real chance. With the three major forces (Berlusconi -yes still him, Renzi and Grillo) agreeing, forcing the current government to withdrawal would not be impossible. Uncertainty: the president still has to agree and could insist on parliament completing its term, imposing an interim government. After all, you do not vote just because and when it's convenient to you...
I may regret it but I am starting to believe that the argument for timing it with Germany's election will lead to early elections.
Renzi is at it again, talking up early elections. But he has always been in favor of that. Remains to be seen whether he will be able to persuade the others, Berlusconi's people in particular.

"Italy's Renzi suggests next election be synchronized with Germany's Former prime minister Matteo Renzi suggested on Sunday that Italy's next election be held at the same time as Germany's, saying this made sense "from a European perspective". Germany will vote on Sept. 24. Elections are due in Italy by May 2018, but speculation is mounting that Italians could head to the polls in the autumn." Moving to 100 percent that the election happens next year. The only possibility I see is that if the current parliament can pass a revised election law there may be an early election near the end of the year. I doubt it but I will have to keep an eye on events.
After Marcon if Merkel is going well in Germany it might encourage the Italians to go to the polls early, though I doubt it.

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/french-presidential-election-results-2017-emmanuel-macron-victory-marine-le-pen-investors-economists-a7723456.html " . . . . the anti-EU Five Star Movement is on course to become the biggest party in Italy’s next election, which will take place either later this year or early next.
The Italian Parliament hasn't even decided what electoral law will be used in the next election.

Gentilloni announced a new economic reform plan that also respects the EC deficit rules. It would be more difficult for the proponents of early elections to argue for such in Q4 then. Besides, they may prefer to let Gentilloni deal with the complications surrounding the 2018 budget first.
Further adjustment away from before October per @sevedb recommendation. Not finding any news about talks for the next election.
Adjust 2 points away from April-June toward rest of 2017
Passage of time renders the early buckets increasingly improbable, and the last bucket is by the far the way to bet.

Shifting heavily toward 2018 because I don't see any evidence than an election is being organized or even that a revised electoral law (a necessary first step) will be passed soon. As well, the PD (the governing party) is still trying to decide on a leader to fight the election and that won't even be until June. That said, Italian politics is extremely fluid and if Renzi wins the PD leadership fight, given his eagerness to become prime minister again, he may then call for an election to be held withing three months of his victory.

Here's what I've learned from @sevedb:
Gentiloni is liked.
The M5S are in more trouble that they can handle. 
Salvini, the leader of North League (a minority party), is disliked.
They all know they may not gain anything as things are now. 
Moreover, Italy GDP now is growing a little more than expected.
As things have changed since last forecast that now seems the most likely.

Gentilloni said he believed his government would serve until 2018. While he is not in full control of the issue, this indicates that forces within the PD don't want early elections. This, plus the financial incentives for MPs to keep Parliament going until September, all but rules out elections in Q2-Q3.
Big readjustment. Very unstable political situation.
Adjusting my forecast due to the passage of time. It is looking less likely that an election will be held in the first half of the year and more likely next year.

Italian politics are among the hardest thing to predict, but let's be brave: Renzi seems to be counting on the 40% that voted for his proposal in tghe referendum. 40% od the popular vote under Italy absurd rukes translates into an absolute majority in parliament.Hence ...

"Italian ruling party leadership vote rules out summer election" http://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-politics-idUSKBN16328C?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews&utm_source=Twitter&utm_medium=Social&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+Reuters%2FworldNews+%28Reuters+World+News%29

A few things that have happened and have been brought to my attention. 1) the significant split within the PD has likely weakened their hand and will make them feel less powerful heading into an election 2) there is a deadline for the submission of the government budget to the EU in October, so there will need to be a government in place around then. Here is where I am conflicted: I think that there is still a desire for early elections, but the timing is becoming more complicated. I am inclined to believe that it would be difficult to get a September election done, but any EU deadlines in October make it hard to do a Q4 election.

Renzi quitting the party leadership and triggering an in-party re-election, which will take place in April or May has effectively ended the possibility of snap elections in Q2 even though all the talk was pointing to that outcome earlier. Since general elections are scheduled for next year, and there still remains issues with the voting system, with the elections not able to take place before they are resolved, it seems there is very little possibility of them happening this year.

The next Italian general election is due to be held no later than 23 May 2018, that is to say no later than seventy days after the natural expiration of the current five-year parliamentary term on 15 March 2018. It is already 2017, likely 1 one more year.

So the news seems to be that Renzi did not want elections in June, but was hoping to go in September: http://www.ansa.it/english/news/politics/2017/02/15/renzi-rules-out-june-elections_a45aa2ab-e0a6-4ada-a34a-af2c17ed23b0.html
But abrupt change of plan - now he has resigned and is seeking re-election https://www.ft.com/content/e59e404a-f6ad-11e6-9516-2d969e0d3b65
Whether Renzi wins re-election or not, I think PD will want an immediate election before the economy tanks. Anyone know how long a PD leadership election is likely to take?
unlikly to announce before results in France - and then requires at least 6 mo leadtime.

I made a base rate forecast looking at the probability of different months having an election and the number of months since an election. This time, I finally got around to looking at why governments go for snap elections, listed out several reasons why it occurs and then looked to see if the current Italian political climate represented those reasons, e.g. incumbent government wants to become majority government and so asks for it when poll winds are at their backs. Or if political scandal forces the President to call an early election. After taking this into account, I made a rough estimate of its effects and so this new forecast is mostly based on President Mattarella's stance on not going for an early election while the electoral laws Italicum are lopsided and Parliament hasn't sorted it out yet. 
I also weighed in my confidence in my research so didn't move from 68% Not before 1 January 2018 to 90% and went for a smaller increment instead.  You can check out my very long blog post for more details. http://jackiesnacks.weebly.com/forecasting/italian-elections-update-a-deeper-forecast
Mild adjustment due to time. Cleared April 2017, added one point to Oct-Dec bucket.

Renzi wants elections in June or September and has surprised opponents in his own party with his call for a leadership vote ASAP. A schism is possible, making a victory in the elections for Beppe Grillo much more likely:
http://www.politico.eu/article/matteo-renzis-democratic-party-tries-to-avoid-schism-italy-leadership-early-elections/?utm_content=buffere1777&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer
Announcement o party congress, which could take up to 3 months to plan, really starts to take July and September off the table.

Stories on Renzi stepping down from leadership and potential challenges to his return I think confirm that elections will be further out.  https://www.ft.com/content/bfc249e2-f208-11e6-8758-6876151821a6

I'm making a big change by shifting most weight to the 2018 option, thanks to @sevedb and the following
http://www.dw.com/en/former-italy-pm-renzi-calls-for-party-reform-leadership-contest/a-37539022 "Former Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi .. has requested early elections, which seems increasingly unlikely......Italian parliamentary elections are currently scheduled for 2018. Current opinion polls show the PD neck and neck with the populist Five Star Movement, led by comedian-turned-political activist Beppe Grillo, and fellow anti-immigration party Northern League - both of which have also called for early elections. Parliament has yet to agree to a new electoral law. Senior Italian political sources have told Reuters they expect current Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni to continue leading the legislature for the rest of the term, though one of Renzi's allies told Reuters Renzi has not lost hope of a national election in June."

According to recent polls, undecided voters are 17.2% while abstaining are 36.6%. Practically 53.8% or the majority of Italians, will go to vote in case of elections.
49.8% responded that they should go to early elections in June. 38.6% believe that the actual Gentiloni's government should get to the end of Parliament in 2018. While 11.6% of voters did not have an opinion. Another poll estimates The Democratic Party is in the lead in the elector preferences. The M5s at a short distance, with 29.5% of the vote. As for the other parties: Italian Left 3.6%, Forza Italy 12.0%, Brothers of Italy 4.7%, Ncd 3, 1%, the Northern League 13,8%, Other parties 4.2%.
____________________________
COMMENTS:  While the above first numbers seem favoring that the Italians will go to vote for a new government (53% is not a lot); popular sentiment is not quite that way. Italian have little faith and patience left for their Government/leaders. However, leaders are now divided: Renzi, who in case of elections and a majority in the seats of Parliament would become again PM; is thinking again. After all the NO at the referendum was a NO to him as PM than anything else. Perhaps he was told to hold his horses M5S are having internal troubles and scandals of their own. Particularly bad is the appointment of the Mayor of Rome, Ms. Raggi, an unexperienced and ingenuous too young lady, who seems to get into troubles endlessly. Salvini, leader of a minority party, and the most "anti-EU/EURO-pro-Trump-Le Pen-Wilders" will never made it to much as it will need to be in coalition with probably FI Berlusconi, who as he awaits another trial for corruption in April, and the Court in Strasbourg did not yet (if ever) give him the green light to a candidacy, just declared:
"You can not go to vote in June. The elections on November 1 are impossible. Lead the country to the polls in these conditions is irresponsible " he obviously prefer Elections as late as possible (he thinks he doesn't age!) But the major deterrent to early elections may be the spread between Italian 10-year sovereign bonds and the benchmark German Bund.  The yield spread between French ten-year bonds and German rose to 72 basis points. Accordingly even the Italian spreads, rose again above 200 points share, for the first time since February 2014.
Upadating as haöf of this quarter has passed now.

Yet to do much additional reading on this. Following logic like this
1: Court's move on the Italicum means that the current PD government is more comfortable holding elections now because the threat of M5S coming to power in a second round runoff is gone.
2: time is needed to harmonize the election laws to some extent, and we don't have a ton of time left before April
3: Summer is hard, Europeans go on vacation and establishment parties see this as too important to do when people are distracted by holidays, still they may want to hammer it in by September
4: as the longest serving Italian government in the last 60 some odd years, they may not wish to throw it in if they don't have to. Especially if they think time works on their side and against M5S.
they will argue till the end before march 2018, but not before jan 2018.
I had been thinking June, but per @Rene I guess Renzi is backing off of that.
"Italy's Renzi signals willingness to ditch push for early vote" http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-italy-politics-idUKKBN15I1L2

"Early elections go up in smoke The ruling of the Constitutional Court on the Italicum electoral system puts paid to those who were gunning for early elections. Following the Court's pronunciation, the Senate will now be elected based on a purely proportional system with preferences but with an election threshold set at 8% for individual parties and 20% for coalitions. In the House of Deputies on the other hand, there will be no coalitions or preferences, but a majority premium for the party that is granted at least 40% of the vote, with no second ballot. Mechanisms that are clearly at odds with each other and if applied without any changes, would wipe out the small parties in the upper house. The ruling now means that the parliament has to take steps to align the two electoral systems. A result that certainly empowers the current government. The tendency towards a return to a proportional electoral system, which many political forces have solicited, will almost automatically lead to the formation of a grand coalition government following the vote in February 2018. Perhaps out of inertia, or the need for a little propaganda, or perhaps because they haven't yet clearly reckoned with the effects of the Court's ruling, a few party leaders are calling for an immediate vote. These are skirmishes to little effect, seeing as one first has to await the publication of the motivations of the ruling (middle of February), and then engage in a reform which, as repeatedly called for by the President of the Italian Republic, Sergio Mattarella, shall provide the country with a uniform electoral law for both Houses of Parliament. The effect of the decision therefore strengthens the government led by Paolo Gentiloni, who will thus be in a position to keep working until the end of the legislature. " Source: http://www.eastonline.eu/en/opinions/eastwest-online/political-weekly-news-italy-30-january-2017

Constitutional issue now out of the way and the major parties seem to want to have an election pretty soon. http://www.politico.eu/article/italian-court-revises-election-law-clearing-way-for-new-poll-elections/
As things stand, Italy seems to have a government that is muddling through - if elections aren't called in an deliberate, timely fashion, I expect the first crisis will trigger them anyway.
October, after current MPs and Senators vest in their pensions.

Mr Renzi and few others are agitating for elections as soon as possible. Despite his humiliation in the referendum, Mr Renzi is hoping that he can preserve momentum from his time in office to retain control of the party, and regain the leadership of the country. He thus makes for an odd bedfellow of Beppe Grillo, the leader of the main opposition group, the populist Five Star Movement; and of Matteo Salvini, who leads the radical-right Northern League.
Strong forces are pulling in the opposite direction. Silvio Berlusconi, the head of Forza Italia, needs to buy time: he hopes to wrest back the leadership of the right-wing camp from Mr Salvini and is waiting for the outcome of an appeal to the European Court of Human Rights against his conviction for tax fraud. If upheld, it would allow him to run again for office. There are more venal motives, too: if parliament is dissolved before September, almost two-thirds of the deputies and senators (those who entered parliament at the last election in 2013) will lose their right to a pension. Parliament could yet limp on to the end of its term in 2018.
http://www.economist.com/news/europe/21715723-humiliated-voters-and-courts-former-prime-minister-still-hopes-retain-political
The Constitutional court rejected, just part of the “Italicum,” the electoral law of the previous Renzi government, therefore early elections could be more likely. It would be enough to make a few changes, to go to elections with two electoral systems in the House and Senate, as preferred by Gentiloni and the Quirinale (President).
However, the EU is not particularly well-disposed towards the Italian government. Italy last year received 19 billion “flexibility”  on its fiscal consolidation, this year it has received other 7 but the EU - which has stretched the rules to the maximum - calls for a minimum intervention of 3.4 billion on the structural deficit. Italian debt is sailing at around 133% of GDP. The EU is demanding Italy to take actions to make the debt to decline.
Mr. Matteo Renzi, would be ready to “challenge the EU” (while Gentiloni would be cautious). His strategy would be to defy the EU on the intervention towards the deficit; while also hoping to earn support, perhaps, by the Italians, when it comes time to go to the polls. The Treasury is preparing for the worst, checking possible effects of the spread in the case of a refusal to observe the EU demands. Practically checking that if the government saves 3.4 billion, would that cost twice as much on the markets, for a country that lives a year of political uncertainty, without even an A rating, and the ECB Quantitative Easing ECB being reduced.
________________________
COMMENTS:  All of the above translates with a Mr. Renzi missing  his chair at Palazzo Chigi; (Gentiloni may be enjoying it and reluctant to let go; the aristocratic Gentiloni may even be more likable than Renzi).  Like all politicians Renzi counts on his popularity (is he really?) and in early elections to have a sufficient majority,  to be PM again. He never conducted a campaign before, he became PM because he maneuvered to withdraw support to the Letta Government (April to November 2013); he managed to oumaneuvered Berlusconi as well in that occasion.  Grillo or M5S, clamored for early elections immediately after the referendum, but he is now holding his horses as his party and leaders are entangled in scandals and many lack sufficient experience (the Mayor of Rome is a notable example) Lega Nord (LN) a Right-wing populist party led by Matteo Salvini; navigates on the fortunes of Le Pen, Trump, Wilders. The new trial will focus on the accusation that the billionaire businessman paid more than 10m euros, between 2011 and 2015, to get witnesses to testify in his favour. Base rate: Snap elections have been called 5 times of 17 parliamentary sessions since 1948 ~ 30% base rate for one to be called before end of term in March 2018, 5 quarters from now, so 6% base rate per quarter (76% for the last choice). It depends on how the legal process related to the electorial law plays out.  New elections are required by 23 May, 2017 (70 days after the expiration of the current parliamentary term).   Under the prior electorial law the Democratic Party (PD) won 297 seats, increased now to 303 seats, in the 630 seat Chamber of Deputies. Grillo's Populist party won 109, since reduced to 91.  This election law used closed party lists. Under the new Chamber of Deputies law:
Under the new "Italicum" election law, the rules have changed.  It is a two round system. The first round is proportional representation based open party lists.  Coalitions are not allowed, all parties must compete separatly. A second round, will be held in the event that no party obtains 40% of the available seats.  If the 40% threshold is passed in the first round, the party with the largest seat count is given 340 seats (54% of the 630 total seat count). The rest of the competing parties (with a minimum of 3% of the vote), recieve the remaining 290 seats in proportion to the percentage of the vote they obtained.
  If no party achieves the 40% threshhold,  a second round of voting takes place with only the top two parties competing against each other for the prize of the 340 seat majority.  The remainder of the seats are then allocated as outlined in round one. 
  Current opinion polls show that neither of the leaders, PD or the M5S has 40% of the vote, although the second round polling lists M5S with an advantage.
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_next_Italian_general_election There are many complications. There are at least two possible legal challenges to the new Cambrr of Deputy law. The referendum to install the accompanying Senate reform law failed to be passed, leaving the Chamber and the Senate with differing election laws. Consider possible motivations for the PD to call early elections. If the new election law is used, M5S may get a 54% majority.  If the court challenges are allowed to play out, either the old election law will be used, or the opportunity is available to renegotiate the laws before another election, either option would be preferred to the M5S majority. Second, prior elections were held with closed, party selected, lists. The new law uses open lists , for the first time, anyone can run, possibly requiring a longer campaign to introduce the candidates.  PD also suggests that the restriction on coalitions in the first round of the elections should be changed (M5S is unlikely to have coalition partners).  If the current Chamber laws are upheld, there seems to be no reason for PD to call early elections.  If the current laws are overturned in the courts, and there is no effort to renegotiate the election laws; PD seems to have an advantage over M5S under an early election based on the prior election law.
Well, if Gentiloni has another health scare, all bets are off.

Italy's outgoing Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said he expects there will be early elections in June, according to an interview in which he wished his replacement, Paolo Gentiloni, good luck.
"The next elections, presumably in June, will be held with a proportional voting system," Renzi said in an interview with Quotidiano.net, though he said he expected parliamentarians to resist a vote before September because that is when they would qualify for their state pensions.
President Sergio Mattarella asked Gentiloni, who was foreign minister in Renzi's government, to form a government on Sunday, and he may accept the mandate as early as Monday. The current legislature is not scheduled to end until 2018

COMMENTS: Renzi is stating some wishful thinking here. let's not forget that Renzi got to power by political manipulation, Letta's government was more legitimate after all.  Gentiloni is a much more likable and knowleageable than Renzi, how political astute we don't know yet. But I do think that a delay by parliamentarians to September is likely. The other one clamoring for an early vote was the M5S (Grillo), but they are having a lot of shortcomings lately--Raggi the naive Major of Rome, the pathetic move by Grillo to quit Farage and  allied themselves with ALDE (The Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe) and the humiliating rejection; along with other amateurish moves may give the M5S a hint that early elections won't translate in a lot of votes for them.
PS:  Italy never holds voting during the summer months: Between 1 July 2017 and 30 September 2017, inclusive

Interim government has won approval in both the lower house and the Senate.  Useful delays are a pension eligibility goal in September, the need to reconcile voting rules across the lower house and the Senate, and a possible motivation to let the French and German elections reduce populist momentum and support for the 5 Star Movement.

Before new general elections are called for, a new lection law needs be passed, as the current one is not applicable to the senate. While potentially risolveable in short time (e.g. voting an earlier law), this is unlikely to happen in time for new elections being called to be held with April. Current members of parliament have an incentive to delay the process further to maintain office until September, when pension entitlements mature, thus a better chance for the time to September, but still limited. I see an increased probability for the end of the year, but more likely to come to a regular end of term.
